Package com.teksystems.salestaxexercise.tax

Class AbstractTaxJurisdiction

java.lang.Object
com.teksystems.salestaxexercise.tax.AbstractTaxJurisdiction
All Implemented Interfaces:
TaxJurisdiction
Direct Known Subclasses:
CanadianTaxJurisdiction
public abstract class AbstractTaxJurisdiction
extends java.lang.Object
implements TaxJurisdiction
Abstract implementation of the logic that should be the same for every TaxJurisdiction.
Author:
Andrew

    • getTaxableCategoryFor

      public TaxableCategory getTaxableCategoryFor​(SellableItem sellableItem)
      Description copied from interface: TaxJurisdiction
      Get the tax category of a specific product or service in this jurisdiction.

      TODO: SOLID design principles suggest maybe this shouldn't be here. There may be tax jurisdictions where all taxes are universally applied to all goods and services, meaning there is no need to keep track of categories. So this method should be split out in to a separate interface that extends this one, specifically for jurisdictions that require categories.

      Specified by:
      getTaxableCategoryFor in interface TaxJurisdiction
      Parameters:
      sellableItem - the item to be sold
      Returns:
      The taxable category for this item in this jurisdiction.

    • getAllTaxes

      public java.util.LinkedHashSet<Tax> getAllTaxes()
      Get the set of taxes which apply in this tax jurisdiction. Must not contain any duplicate taxes and must be maintained in a particular order, as some taxes may be applied on top of other taxes prior to them on the list e.g., Quebec sales taxes are applied on top of the Canadian federal GST. The SOLID design principle that interfaces should wherever possible depend on other interfaces, not concrete classes, would suggest this should return a Set or a List, not a LinkedHashSet. If there was a generic Java collection interface that ensured both the uniqueness (like Set) AND order (like List) of is elements, I would definitely use it here. But as far as I know there is no such interface, only the class LinkedHashSet enforces both. So I decided in this case the benefits of depending on the concrete class outweighed the loss of flexibility. This implementation will not allow this method to ever return null.
      Specified by:
      getAllTaxes in interface TaxJurisdiction
      Returns:
      The ordered set of all taxes for this jurisdiction. Never null for this implementation.

    • getTaxAmountsFor

      public java.util.LinkedHashMap<Tax,​org.joda.money.Money> getTaxAmountsFor​(SellableItem sellableItem)
      Get an ordered map of all the individual taxes and their amounts for the specified sellable item. The SOLID design principle that interfaces should wherever possible depend on other interfaces, not concrete classes, would suggest this should return a Map, not a LinkedHashMap. However, because some taxes may be assessed on top of other taxes, maintaining the order of taxes may be very important in many implementations. I decided the benefits of forcing every implementer to implement with a structure that maintains order outweighed the potential loss in flexibility. This implementation will not allow this method to ever return null.
      Specified by:
      getTaxAmountsFor in interface TaxJurisdiction
      Parameters:
      sellableItem - the item to be sold
      Returns:
      An ordered map of taxes and their respective amounts for the specified sellable item. Never null for this implementation.

    • toString

      public java.lang.String toString()
      Get a printable string that identifies this this tax jurisdiction. This implementation just calls the toString() method on the underlying getRegion() object. Can never be null or empty.
      Overrides:
      toString in class java.lang.Object
      Returns:
      A printable string that identifies this tax jurisdiction. Never null or empty.

    • getPrimaryKey

      public java.lang.String getPrimaryKey()
      Get the primary key identifying this tax jurisdiction. This implementation just returns the toString() value for this object. This is a hack, in the real world each jurisdiction would likely have a unique key defined in the data source.
      Returns:
      A string that uniquely identifies this tax jurisdiction. Never null or empty.

    • equals

      public boolean equals​(java.lang.Object obj)
      Check if another object is equal to this one. This implementation requires the other object to also extend AbstractTaxJurisdiction, and for its getPrimaryKey() method to return a value that equals this object's getPrimaryKey().
      Overrides:
      equals in class java.lang.Object
      Parameters:
      obj - the object to compare to this one

    • hashCode

      public int hashCode()
